text: The instant I break from the shield line, the world twists into wind and snow. The rim of a shield scrapes my shoulder, iron grinding against ice with a shrill scream.
The snow beneath my boots softens under the Demon King’s ‘breath,’ as if it might collapse into a pit at any second. I nearly trip over a slab of broken stone—but force that step steady.
I’m not running to kill it. I’m here to steal back half a second from between the black mist’s teeth.
I swallow air into my lungs—swallow the fear with it. Then I hurl my voice forward—harder than the wind.
“Alicia—! No matter how many times it takes, I’ll wait for you!”
The wind tears at the words—but they don’t break. They stretch like a taut line, catching at her heart.
Her trembling fingers steady at once.
Even the Demon King’s mist falters for a fraction of a second—like it has noticed a ‘variable’ in the loop.
The Demon King tilts its head—not in rage, but in confusion.
The mist coiled around her wrist loosens by a thread.
“…Don’t run around.”
She doesn’t look back. The words are both command and protection.
She moves along that narrow opening—not faster, just more precise.
She flips her wrist and draws out the necklace. The pendant burns in the black light, but she grips it without hesitation.
The mist tries to recoil—but the Demon King’s focus lingers on me, half a beat too slow.
Half a beat is the distance between life and death.
“End.”
She slams the necklace into the core’s fracture. The moment it sinks in, blazing white veins erupt outward from within.
The Demon King howls, distorted and tearing. Its bone armor cracks apart, fractures climbing toward the sky.
She pulls her sword free and steps back—then takes one step toward me, as if finally allowing herself to admit she is not alone.
But the core collapses behind her.
The shockwave explodes outward. Snow and shattered stone rise in a white tidal surge. The city walls tremble. She is thrown toward me.
In midair, she twists, turning her back to the blast—shielding me from the worst of it.
She crashes down beside me, shoulder armor shattered. Her breath stutters—yet her hand still reaches to make sure I’m here.
“You did it…”
At the blast’s center, the Demon King’s form disintegrates. The black mist falls away like torn curtains, fragment by fragment.
At last, the Demon King vanishes completely. The rift stitches itself closed, and the sky’s strange light slowly fades.
The wind stops.
And the suffocating sense of countdown pressing on the world—stops with it.
